data.text: Should I Buy Patagonia Houdini Water RESISTANT jacket?

Iâ€™m about to buy the Patagonia Houdini packable waterRESISTANT jacket. Before I do so does anybody have any other recommendations for a very small compact, maybe more waterproof jacket? Iâ€™m not into spending hundreds of dollars unfortunately Thanks!

I really like my rei brand rain jacket, it packs down decently and the price isn't so bad. I'm sure the men's version is just as good. https://www.rei.com/product/127274/rei-co-op-rainier-rain-jacket-womens
REI Co-op Rainier Rain Jacket - Women's | REI Co-op
rei.com
data.author: Caitlin McCauley

data.text: Houdini is an ultralight windbreaker (i.e., no WP coating nor laminate) although a bit more water resistant than most windbreakers. I have used my Houdini for for trail running and hikes, but not for bicycling. For bicycle touring, I'd recommend a more stormworthy shell. PU-coated (vs. ePTFE laminate) will be the least expensive. Marmot PreCip (lightweight hiking/backpacking/climbing) shell which, at 11 oz., is not as light as a Houdini, but quite stormworthy for its weight, and available for around $75 on sale. Or you could look at bicycle-specific jackets, although I suggest you confirm whether the jacket has ePTFE (e.g., GoreTex) or PU-coating if you want something stormworthy vs. a mere windbreaker. The advantage of a bicycle-specific jacket is that it will likely be cut long in the back to cover your tush better while in riding position. Showers Pass Century and Syncline jackets are examples of bicycle-specific rain shells on the more stormworthy/affordable end of the scale.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: I use the Houdini for biking. The only time I can tolerate waterproof is temps below 40 and rain. Canâ€™t speak to the Marmot, but it sounds like a good middle option!
data.author: Barbara L. Blackford

data.text: , actually, the PreCip does not breathe very well, but it's quite stormworthy. ePTFE breathes much better, but is more expensive. Have you tried a lightweight ePTFE (e.g., GoreTex) shell with pit zips over a lightweight base layer? I'm a heavy sweater and that combo works for me at 55F or lower -- or 65F if it's very stormy. IME, a heavy rain will penetrate a Houdini within a few minutes, rendering me soaked to the bone. IMV, the choice of shell somewhat depends on the route. If a tour includes high mountain passes, a Houdini would not be stormworthy enough for me. Having encountered some very nasty weather in the mountains -- including snow blizzards in August -- I am inclined to pack a shell on the more stormworthy end of the spectrum.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: I thought gore Tex was a fabric as opposed to a coating?
data.author: Marcus Murray

data.text: , GoreTex (GTX) is a fabric with Gore's proprietary ePTFE laminate. There are other ePTFE laminate fabrics, e.g., eVent. Polyurethane (PU) coated fabric shells are less expensive, but do not breathe nearly as well as ePTFE-coated fabrics. Also, GTX fabrics come in different weights and stormworthiness levels. The GTX shell I use for mid-winter storm skiing is much heavier than the lightweight GTX shell I use for summer mountaineering, which is a bit heavier than my ultralightweight GTX bicycle jacket.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: gotcha. Thanks
data.author: Marcus Murray

data.text: In the marmot range, the essence is much better than the precip in terms of breathability, similar weight and cut. However, more $. Basically you get what you pay forðŸ˜‰
data.author: Andrew Robinson

data.text: , I'm not familiar with the Essence, which has been discontinued. Per Marmot specs, the PreCip and Essence use the same "2.5 layer NanoPro MemBrain" [PU] coating. (Note that the fabric of recent PreCip jackets breathe better than older ones.) Why would the Essence be more breatheable? I did note that the Essence is lighter due to no pit zips, no hand pockets and lighter (15D body, 40D shoulders) fabric.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: got it. Thanks for the info. I agree that Iâ€™d want to have waterproof available for most tours. The tours Iâ€™ve done (and those tours donâ€™t involve camping), I carry waterproof. Iâ€™ve just found that in order to not roast in waterproof, for me it has to be raining or snowing and below 40-42f. Above that, I generally prefer being wet, with the wind resistance provided by something like the Houdini. I also tend to use a vest more than either - it has to be pretty cool for me to even use the Houdini. It all depends on where you are going, options for getting out of the elements and your individual thermostat. The vast majority of folks probably need something waterproof in their arsenal.
data.author: Barbara L. Blackford

data.text: , I also carry a vest instead of a windbreaker. FWIW, I have learned much more about layering, sweat control, venting and storm gear from mountaineering, backpacking, ski touring and ski mountaineering than from bicycle touring. This is not the place to start a discussion re semi-vapor barriers, which I find invaluable in cold wet weather.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: I bet! You have my respect and admiration for those activities! The biggest issue I have on the bike are my feet. Wool socks, shoe covers - none of it works, because my feet get wet from sweat. I can regulate the rest of my body through cold, rain and snow. (And no problem running or hiking, but Iâ€™m also not running in the cold and stopping as you would if you were spending days outside. I run, change clothes and go home.)
data.author: Barbara L. Blackford

data.text:
, foot sweat is a big issue when ski touring/ski mountaineering in spring and summer. I've had some luck with Certain Dri antiperspirant. Vapor barrier (VB) socks can work well in very cold or cold/wet weather, but only if you learn to tolerate having a damp foot all day. I've had best luck with 2mm neoprene socks (used by cold weather kayakers). Andrew Skurka has some good info re VBs. https://andrewskurka.com/vapor-barrier-liners-theory-application/
Vapor Barrier Liners: Theory & Application - Andrew Skurka
andrewskurka.com
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: , here's a link to a thread re semi-VBs on a hiking forum. I suggest you ignore the first post (largely irrelevent) and start with the second post (which I contributed). http://www.nwhikers.net/forums/viewtopic.php?p=914493
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: thank you!!!!
data.author: Barbara L. Blackford

data.text: maybe they have changed. I have both an essence and precip, around 4 years old. The material on the precip feels thicker and stiffer, more like the patagonia torrent shell (which I also have). The essence is similar to wear to my 7mesh goretex jacket, light and breathable. All irrelevant though, if the essence has been discontinued.
data.author: Andrew Robinson

data.text: , the PreCip fabric is indeed thicker and stiffer because it's 50D vs. Essense mix of 15D and 40D fabric. My point is that they use the same PU coating, which is very different that an ePTFE laminate, e.g., GoreTex.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: The above comments are spot on. I do take a Showers Pass Elite 2.1 bike touring in addition to my Houdini. I like it as an extra insulation layer, and for a crisp snap in the air. They have orange which would be good for visibility....purchased the Houdini without regrets. My favorite all around lightweight jacket!
data.author: Frosene Sacco

data.text: Yeah. Houdini is awesome for wind and extra warmth at minimal weight, but not rain. I have an outdoor research helium that mostly replaced my Houdini. A little more weight, but waterproof. Good for got caught rainstorms or on a summer tour. I take my showers pass if I expect prolonged rain.

data.text: I checked out that OR jacket, I think thatâ€™s the winner!

data.text: FYI, Iâ€™ve got 3 Houdinis Iâ€™ve bought over the years, and Iâ€™ve always gotten them on sale. So if you decide to go with that, look for a sale - usually last yearâ€™s model and color, but that wasnâ€™t important to me.
data.author: Barbara L. Blackford

data.text: , agreed! I got mine on sale too!
data.author: Frosene Sacco

data.text: I have a Patagonia Torrentshell. Bought it on the recommendation of my favorite salesperson at a big retailer, and because I liked the fit and features - zippers, etc. Recently found that it was also a favorite of the NY Times Wirecutter reviews. I have not used it for anything but light rains so far, and it was good for that, but my experience with a few different rain jackets is that nothing will keep you totally dry if you are riding in a storm for an hour or two.
data.author: Carlos Alcala

data.text: , Patagucci Torrentshell is very similar to the Marmot PreCip I mentioned in my first post. Both are inexpensive PU-coated, not so breatheable, but quite stormworthy. I wouldn't be surprised if both use the same fabric or fabric from the same supplier.
data.author: Steve Loitz

data.text: I have a houdini and it's great, but it is NOT waterproof. I bought an Outdoor Research Helium jacket for that purpose. It's slightly larger than a Houdini when packed, but it is fully waterproof with a generous hood.

data.text: I have the Mountain Hardware Women's Exposure/2â„¢ Gore-Tex PacliteÂ® Plus Jacket and LOVE IT! It isnâ€™t cheap (though I bought it at the outlet and it was 40% off, making the price tag much more palatable) but it is very waterproof, packs down super small, and weights less than 3 oz.
data.author: Erin Ballou Kraus

data.text: , are you sure about that weight? The spec on the MH website is incorrect. (Several reviewers have mentioned that, but MH has failed to correct the erroneous spec.) That jacket actually weighs between 8.5 oz. (W small) and 12.5 oz. (men's XL). It would be impossible to make a GTX Paclite shell lighter than 7 oz. or so.

data.author: Pamela Murray

data.text: For bike touring I pack the Showers Pass Elite 2.1. It is not ultra-compact ultra-small but it is reliable, good with rain, and provides some warmth. For warm weather I have the Gore Active Shakedry "1985" and it is awesome and ultra-small ultra-light, but it is also fragile, and it wouldn't be my first choice for doing extensive bike-touring.
data.author: Pierre Moreels

data.text: Grundens weather watch jacket if you are going to be in continuous rain. Wear wool and fleece underneath. No cotton. All these "breathable" high tech jackets are trash when you are in ongoing rain and will eventually soak through. With a hardshell like Grundens, you will get body condensation but that's a better problem to have than your so called rain jacket getting saturated and causing hypothermia.
data.author: Daren Eaken

data.text: Thanks everyone for your recommendations!!

data.text: I have the Houdini, and like Ben Alter said, it isnâ€™t really waterproof. I also have Frogg Toggs, they pack well but are so waterproof I got soaked from sweating so much. If itâ€™s colder and not very humid they work great if itâ€™s hot and humid you are better off getting wet and drying off later.

data.author: David Housley

data.text: If REI doesn't have something better and cheaper...something is wrong. I have an Endura and an old Columbia Titanium from 25yrs ago. In all cases i'd consider GORE that makes REAL gear over Patagonia (a lifestyle brand) at a similar price. In reality, for performance cycling apparel, Patagonia doesn't exist in that space....at all. Except for maybe a nano puff for when you're off the bike.

data.text: Have the Houdini and love it. Obviously provides some water resistance, but also great as a wind breaker and for general warmth in spring and fall temps.
data.author: Jon Harding

data.text: I run an alpine Houdini on my rides, good jacket but it is ultralight and breathability is low so expect it to catch body moisture. Needs to be washed regularly to avoid sweat degradation.
data.author: Tim Matthee

data.text: I have the Houdini. Itâ€™s great for wind and definitely adds some warmth. Itâ€™s also fairly water resistant, enough to get by if temperatures arenâ€™t too low. I wear it a lot , sometimes as a mid layer too.
